conclusion: Understanding the Stirling cycle involves two isochoric and two isobaric processes.
In an isochoric process, volume remains constant but temperature can change.
In an isobaric process, pressure remains constant but volume and temperature can change.
Process D→A is isobaric, meaning pressure remains constant while volume changes.
During an isobaric process, temperature changes as the gas absorbs or releases heat.
The rate distribution curve of gas molecules depends on the temperature of the gas.
Since the temperature changes during process D→A, the rate distribution curve will change.
The rate distribution curve shifts towards higher energies as temperature increases.
The rate distribution curve shifts towards lower energies as temperature decreases.
Since the temperature changes during the isobaric process D→A, the rate distribution curve of the gas molecules will also change.
Final Answer: Yes, the rate distribution curve of the gas molecule changes during the process from state D to state A.
